Award.AwardTitle: New Tools for Genetic Analysis in Arabidopsis thaliana

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will produce a novel, enhanced set of tools (Traffic Lines) that will increase the speed and lower the cost of performing genetic analysis in the model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana. As a community resource, these lines will facilitate the research of a large number of investigators studying a wide range of biological problems in this important model organism, and will also be useful for teaching basic concepts in genetics at a high school or college level. The project will provide training for a postdoctoral fellow and undergraduate students.

Traffic Lines (TLs) are genetic stocks of Arabidopsis thaliana that contain linked seed-specific transgenes expressing green or red fluorescent proteins. TLs facilitate genetic mapping by enabling investigators to identify recombinants in a region of interest using dry seeds, without the need for molecular analysis. The lines make it possible to identify individuals homozygous for recombinant chromosomes in a segregating population, increasing the reliability with which the phenotypes of these recombinants can be assessed. The lines also will be useful for maintaining recessive lethal alleles. 150 TLs covering the entire Arabidopsis genome in 1 mB intervals will be generated in the Columbia ecotype by recombining closely-linked pNAP::eGFP and pNAP::dsRED insertions onto a single chromosome. Ten TLs covering larger regions of the genome will also be generated in Landsberg erecta. Stocks useful for a high school or college laboratory exercise in genetic recombination will also be generated.

This project is funded by the Genetic Mechanisms Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Traffic lines are transgenic stocks of Arabidopsis thaliana that contain two linked seed-specific green fluoresdent and red fluorescent transgenes. These lines have two major advantages for genetic analysis. First, they enable investigators to visually screen thousands of dry seeds for seeds that are the products of recombination in a defined region of a chromosome.  Second, they make it possible to determine the genotype of a seed prior to planting. These lines save investigators the time and cost associated with molecular genotyping, and eliminate the environmental cost associated with this wasteful technology. The goal of this proposal was to generate a set of Traffic lines that parse the Arabidopsis genone into 1-to-2 mB marked segments. Over 170 such lines were generated; together with previously generated lines, this brings the total number of Traffic lines to 230. Homozygous stocks of these lines were amplified for distribution through the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center. A line suitable for teaching the principles of genetic mapping to undergraduates was produced, and the feasibility of this exercise was tested using a protocol employed in Introductory Biology classes at the University  of Pennsylvania. This test demonstrated that it is difficult to visualize seed flouorescence without the use of a research grade fluorescence microscope.
